column4: I've been having trouble changing the permissions and owner of files.  I have an interchange partition for working with things in both Linux and windows, but I've found that when I make a file in Windows, put it in that partition, and boot Linux, it will only allow root to access the file with write permissions.  I've tried actually logging in as root (beyond just sudo and su -), and when I try to change permissions from the command
line, it seems to work, but does not actually, and chown replies that it is unable to do that.
Any ideas?
No, the partition is a FAT.
However, the main drive of Windows is NTFS.  Would that matter?
it sounds like a mount issue.   rather than a file permissions issue.
what fs is the interchange partition
add umask=000 to the line in /etc/fstab  that discribes that partition
you should "man fstab "  first.
Where on the line should that go?
you should "man fstab "  first.
I looked in the man page, and unfortunately I don't really understand it, nor did I see any mention of "umask".  I'm guessing this information is all in there, but I'm missing it somehow.
Any more suggestions if I don't understand the man?
put "umask=000" next to the last entry in the line in fstab
/dev/hdc1 /mnt/disk vfat  defaults,umaks=000 0 0  <--- something along that line.
